metadata.titleEn: HiWATER: Dataset of hydrometeorological observation network (No.2 runoff observation system of 312 bridge on the Heihe River, 2013)
metadata.description:
The No. 2 hydrological section is located at 312 Heihe River Bridge (100.411° E, 38.998° N, 1485 m) in the midstream of the Heihe River Basin, Zhangye city, Gansu Province. The dataset contains observations recorded by the No.2 hydrological section from 19 June, 2012, to 31 December, 2013. This section consists of two river sections, i.e., the east section, which is denoted as No. 1 and the west section, which is denoted as No. 2. The width of this section is 90 meters and consists of a gravel bed; the cross-sectional area is unstable because of human factors. The water level was measured using an SR50 ultrasonic range and the discharge was measured using cross-section reconnaissance by the StreamPro ADCP. The dataset includes the following parameters: water level (recorded every 30 minutes) and discharge. The missing and incorrect (outside the normal range) data were replaced with -6999.
For more information, please refer to Li et al. (2013) (for hydrometeorological observation network or sites information), He et al. (2016) (for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Upscaling of eco-hydrological processes on a heterogeneous surface is a grand challenge. Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. HiWATER is an experiment designed to address this challenge through instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales to obtain multiscale and multidisciplinary data.
challenges: Progress in this field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations.
methods: Several intensive observation periods (IOPs) and continuous hydrometeorological observations were carried out during HiWATER. Only data collected during the IOP in 2012 are presented in this paper. Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes. We established a sparse network to investigate the oasis-desert interaction. One superstation was constructed within the oasis, and four EC towers and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations (AMSs) were installed in different landscapes surrounding the oasis, including sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland. Intensive observations were implemented at the irrigation district scale. A total of 12 airborne remote sensing missions were conducted to cover the FEA using LiDAR, an imaging spectrometer, a multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.
dataset: We introduce a multiscale dataset obtained from Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) in an oasis-desert area in 2012. The HiWATER observation system consists of a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations; an eco-hydrological sensor network of soil moisture and leaf area index; hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer; and synchronical ground measurements of vegetation dynamics and photosynthesis processes. All observational data were carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation. The data are freely available at figshare and the Cold and Arid Regions Science Data Centre.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a multiscale data collection method used to study eco-hydrological processes in a heterogeneous surface area?
Example.Answer: A multiscale data collection method used in the Heihe Watershed Allied Telemetry Experimental Research (HiWATER) involves instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales, including a flux observation matrix of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, and automatic meteorological stations, as well as hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing using LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and an L-band microwave radiometer.

Example.Question: What is an example of a challenge faced in collecting multiscale observations for eco-hydrological research?
Example.Answer: A challenge faced in collecting multiscale observations for eco-hydrological research is the poor availability of such observations, which hinders progress in understanding processes on a heterogeneous surface.

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a dataset that includes energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis-desert areas?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset that includes energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis-desert areas is the dataset from the middle and lower reaches of the Heihe River Basin, which has been established since 2012 and is available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What is meant by 'multiscale observations' in the context of eco-hydrological processes?
Definition.Answer: Multiscale observations refer to the collection of data at various spatial and temporal scales to understand complex eco-hydrological processes. This includes using hierarchically nested scales of instrumentation, such as flux observation matrices, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing. These instruments capture data across different landscapes and scales, such as oasis and desert systems, to address challenges in observing heterogeneous surfaces.

Definition.Question: How does the 'eddy covariance system' function in measuring environmental data?
Definition.Answer: The eddy covariance system functions by measuring turbulent fluxes of energy, water vapor, carbon, and methane between the land surface and the atmosphere. This technique involves capturing half-hourly data of these fluxes using specialized sensors that detect changes in air temperature, humidity, and wind speed. The data is used to understand interactions within the oasis-desert ecosystem, contributing to long-term environmental observations.

Definition.Question: What are the challenges in creating 'water level-flow curves' for river observations?
Definition.Answer: Creating water level-flow curves for river observations can be challenging due to the instability of hydrological cross-sections and frequent human disturbances. These factors cause fluctuations in the relationship between water levels and flow rates, making it difficult to obtain consistent and reliable flow data. Such challenges necessitate further observation and refinement of data collection methods to achieve accurate hydrological measurements.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection methods used in the HiWATER experiment compare to those used for the 黑河生态水文遥感试验 in terms of capturing multiscale eco-hydrological processes?
Comparison.Answer: The HiWATER experiment utilized hierarchically nested instrumentation including eddy covariance towers, automatic meteorological stations, and remote sensing technology to capture multiscale eco-hydrological processes. In contrast, the 黑河生态水文遥感试验 focused on river flow measurements using SR50 ultrasonic ranging devices with a fixed frequency of 30 minutes, emphasizing localized hydrometeorological observations.

Interpretation.Question: What role does quality control play in the collection and processing of eco-hydrological datasets, and how is it implemented?
Interpretation.Answer: Quality control is essential in ensuring the accuracy and reliability of eco-hydrological datasets. It is implemented through careful sensor calibration, systematic data collection, rigorous data processing, and the generation of quality-controlled datasets. This process is vital for maintaining the integrity of the collected data and ensuring it is suitable for analysis and interpretation.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the instability in water level-flow curves during data collection in eco-hydrological studies?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The instability in water level-flow curves can be caused by frequent human disturbances and the unstable cross-sectional area of the riverbed, which is often made of gravel and subjected to changes in the hydrological section.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is multiscale observation considered a challenge in eco-hydrological research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Multiscale observation is a challenge in eco-hydrological research due to the poor availability of observations across different scales, which is necessary to understand complex interactions within heterogeneous surfaces, such as those found in oasis-desert systems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the need for long-term observations in oasis-desert ecosystems?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Long-term observations are needed in oasis-desert ecosystems to quantitatively understand the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange, which are crucial for recognizing oasis-desert interactions and ensuring ecological stability and socioeconomic development in these regions.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using a sparse network versus a dense network of observation stations on the accuracy and comprehensiveness of data collected in eco-hydrological studies?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a sparse network can limit the ability to capture detailed interactions and variations within the eco-hydrological processes, potentially leading to less accurate and comprehensive data. A dense network could provide more detailed and robust datasets to better understand the interactions between oasis and desert systems.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does frequent anthropogenic disturbance at hydrometric cross-sections impact the reliability of flow data in hydrological datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Frequent anthropogenic disturbances can lead to instability in the cross-section area, resulting in a disrupted stage-discharge relationship and potentially unreliable flow data. This necessitates further observations to improve data quality and reliability.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the implications of integrating multiscale and multidisciplinary data from diverse instruments on understanding oasis-desert interactions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Integrating multiscale and multidisciplinary data from diverse instruments allows for a more comprehensive understanding of oasis-desert interactions by capturing a wide range of variables and processes. This approach can help address the challenges of understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges, ultimately supporting ecological stability and sustainable development.

Goal Orientation.Question: What are the primary objectives of collecting multiscale and multidisciplinary data in eco-hydrological studies of oasis-desert systems?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objectives are to address the challenge of upscaling eco-hydrological processes on heterogeneous surfaces and to better understand oasis-desert interactions. This is achieved by obtaining multiscale and multidisciplinary data through hierarchically nested scales, which can help in capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes and supporting sustainable development goals in oasis-desert ecosystems.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems in the context of sustainable development?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Maintaining a balance between oasis and desert systems is crucial for achieving sustainable development because it helps ensure ecological security and supports socioeconomic development. Understanding the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these ecosystems is essential for recognizing oasis-desert interactions, achieving carbon neutrality, and protecting the ecological stability of arid regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of using advanced remote sensing technologies in collecting data for hydrological and ecological studies in arid regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Using advanced remote sensing technologies, such as LiDAR, imaging spectrometers, multi-angle thermal imagers, and L-band microwave radiometers, is significant because it allows for hyper-resolution data collection that can capture detailed eco-hydrological processes. This technology supports multiscale observation, which is essential for addressing the challenge of poor availability of multiscale observations and for enhancing the understanding of complex interactions in oasis-desert systems.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are multiscale datasets obtained from eco-hydrological experiments processed and quality controlled to ensure reliability and accuracy?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: All observational data are carefully quality controlled throughout sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and datasets generation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the procedural steps for arranging instruments on hierarchically nested scales to capture multi-scale eco-hydrological processes in a desert-oasis system?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Instruments for the oasis-desert system were arranged in hierarchically nested scales. A sparse network was established to investigate the oasis-desert interaction, including one superstation within the oasis, four EC towers, and four two-layer automatic meteorological stations installed in surrounding landscapes like sandy desert, desert pavement, desert steppe, and wetland.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodologies are employed to handle data gaps and disturbances in hydrological observations due to unstable riverbed conditions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The 2号点-312桥断面 experiences frequent human disturbances and unstable hydrological cross-section areas, leading to chaotic water level-flow curves. Missing data are uniformly represented by the string -6999, indicating the need for further observation to address data gaps.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have facilitated the collection of multiscale eco-hydrological data in oasis-desert systems?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements that have facilitated this include the use of eddy covariance towers, large aperture scintillometers, automatic meteorological stations, and hyper-resolution airborne remote sensing technologies like LiDAR, imaging spectrometer, multi-angle thermal imager, and L-band microwave radiometer.

Enablement.Question: How do intensive observation periods (IOPs) enable more comprehensive data collection in eco-hydrological research?
Enablement.Answer: Intensive observation periods (IOPs) allow for focused data collection efforts using hierarchically nested instrumentation, which captures multiscale eco-hydrological processes through a network of sensors such as EC towers and automatic meteorological stations placed in diverse landscapes.

Enablement.Question: What data processing techniques ensure the quality and reliability of hydrometeorological datasets collected in arid regions?
Enablement.Answer: Data processing techniques that ensure quality and reliability include sensor calibration, data collection, data processing, and quality control procedures, as well as data archiving and sharing, which are essential for maintaining the integrity of hydrometeorological datasets.

Expectation.Answer: Progress in the field is hindered by the poor availability of multiscale observations. Innovative data collection methods, like the instrumentation on hierarchically nested scales used in HiWATER, can help address these challenges by capturing multi-scale eco-hydrological processes.

Judgmental.Answer: The use of multiscale instrumentation, as described in the metadata, is effective in capturing eco-hydrological processes because it involves a hierarchical arrangement of tools like eddy covariance towers and automatic meteorological stations. This setup allows for comprehensive data collection across different scales, which is crucial in understanding complex interactions in oasis-desert systems.

Judgmental.Answer: Maintaining data quality control for long-term observations presents significant challenges due to factors such as instrument calibration, data processing, and environmental changes.
